Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Investigating Machine-Produced Radiation to Improve X-ray Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
Throughout airports and hospitals around the world, x-ray imaging technologies are used for the safety and concern of mankind. For example, these technologies are employed to detect dangerous explosive and illegal drugs by homeland security. The applications are not limited only to medicine and science, but to general industry, and hence the need for cost-effective x-ray sources that are reliable and produce optimal yields is ever present. The dense plasma focus device, which is known as a device that can generate fusion reactions, has recently been established as a very efficient source of x-rays, thus making the desire to find and optimize a high performance and high repetition device tremendous. Presently, such a device has been developed and implemented at the National Institute of Education in Singapore, and work has been done to optimize the performance and enhance its reproducibility. This award funds research to conduct a comprehensive study of dense plasma focus plasmas through the use of x-ray spectroscopy and imaging. Conducting the proposed research under the supervision of Dr. Rajdeep Rawat provides the valuable opportunity of studying radiation and plasma formation from this type of device.

Access to the host?s device will allow for a detailed spectroscopic examination and imaging measurements on pinch plasmas from a dense plasma focus device, which has not yet been done. The ultimate goal of completing this research is to advance knowledge and understanding within the field of pinch plasmas. Specifically, use of spectroscopy, imaging measurements, and theoretical models will enhance the understanding of x-ray emission efficiency from such experiments. Various diagnostic tools such as silicone diodes, x-ray pinhole cameras, and a spectrometer will be used to enhance knowledge about the experimental plasma parameters. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Science Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of a two month period, tremendously exciting research was conducted on a dense plasma focus (DPF) device in Singapore. The major goal for this project was the thorough investigation of X-ray emission from a DPF device, and it was accomplished through the use of detailed X-ray spectroscopy and imaging techniques. The ultimate goal was to advance the knowledge and understanding within the field of plasma physics. Experimental data was collected from X-ray radiation produced by Argon and Krypton plasmas. An X-ray diffraction spectrometer was used in every experiment which collected data on a light sensitive film. This data allows one to observe different line intensities from ionic transitions that occur when an atom is bombarded with energy. In order to interpret these line intensities, two theoretical models were developed. These models produce synthetic spectra with line intensities that depend on the parameters included by the user. Such parameters are plasma temperature, density, and optical thickness. By comparing the theoretical data to the experimental data, one can obtain a greater understanding of the true experimental parameters. Furthermore, a Silicon diode spectrometer was used in every experiment so that the total amount of X-ray energy could be calculated. The data collected on Krypton is of significant interest and importance. Prior to the experiments conducted for this fellowship, almost no data had been collected at all using gases of higher molecular weight on a DPF device. The device is often operated using Deuterium gas since it is a ready source for neutron production. However, when operated with other gases such as Neon, it is good source of soft X-rays. By operating the device with other gases, and using detailed spectroscopy and imaging techniques,  we are able to better understand the X-ray emission efficiency from experiments on a DPF device. Overall, the research that was conducted was highly beneficial to further advance the knowledge about radiation properties from a DPF plasma, as well being relevant to the further development of low energy, high repetition plasma focus devices as radiation sources. Applications of such a device include homeland security, medicine, science, and the general industry. Thus, the search for cost-effective and reliable x-ray sources continues to be of great interest in the scientific community.
